events.event_name: January 2026 HCOB France Composite PMI Release
events.description: The release of the revised Composite PMI data for France in January 2026.

events.event_name: January 2026 Services Business Activity Index Release
events.description: The release of the services sector specific activity index for January.

facts.fact_text: The HCOB France Composite PMI for January 2026 was 49.1, down from 50.0 in December.

evidences.evidence_text: The HCOB France Composite PMI for January 2026 was revised higher to 49.1 from a flash estimate of 48.6, but remained below December’s 50.0.

facts.fact_text: The Services Business Activity Index fell to 48.4 in January from 50.1 in December.

evidences.evidence_text: the services sector, where the Business Activity Index slipped from 50.1 in December to 48.4 in January, marking the first contraction since October.

facts.fact_text: Input cost inflation reached a five-month high in January.

evidences.evidence_text: Meanwhile, input cost inflation edged up to a five-month high, prompting firms to raise output charges modestly.

facts.fact_text: New orders in the private sector declined at the fastest rate in six months.

evidences.evidence_text: New orders across the private sector fell at the fastest pace in six months, while employment recorded only marginal growth.

claims.claim_text: The French private sector is experiencing renewed weakness.
claims.author: HCOB

evidences.evidence_text: The latest reading pointed to renewed weakness in private sector activity, with the downturn driven mainly by the services sector

claims.claim_text: Manufacturing is showing tentative signs of stabilization despite subdued demand.
claims.author: HCOB

evidences.evidence_text: Manufacturing showed only tentative signs of stabilization, with capacity pressures rising but overall demand still subdued.

claims.claim_text: Business confidence for the year ahead is at its highest level since late 2024.
claims.author: HCOB

evidences.evidence_text: Finally, business confidence improved, with year-ahead growth expectations rising to their strongest level since September 2024.

evidence.evidence_text: the downturn driven mainly by the services sector, where the Business Activity Index slipped from 50.1 in December to 48.4 in January
input cost inflation edged up to a five-month high, prompting firms to raise output charges modestly.
Exports continued to weigh on activity, as overseas demand for services remained in contraction.
New orders across the private sector fell at the fastest pace in six months, while employment recorded only marginal growth.
